botanical_details.genus: Lilium are bulbous perennials with erect stems bearing whorled or spirally arranged leaves and terminal racemes or umbels of bowl-shaped, trumpet-shaped, funnel-shaped or turks cap shaped flowers, often fragrant, and white, yellow, orange or red

how_to_grow.cultivation: Plant bulbs in autumn, 15 cm deep, in acidic or neutral, moist but well-drained soil enriched with leaf mould or well-rotted organic matter, in a sheltered position, with the base of the plant in shade, for example from ground-cover plants, and the rest of the plant in full sun or light dappled shade
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by division: separate bulblets as the leaves die down
how_to_grow.pruning: No pruning required, but deadheading will improve their appearance
how_to_grow.pests: May be affected by lily beetle, aphids, slugs, snails, thrips, leathejackets, and wireworms, and by rabbits and voles; plants in containers may be affected by vine weevil
how_to_grow.diseases: May be affected by lily disease, other fungal diseases, and virus diseases; for more advice see lily diseases
